Award.AwardTitle: Algorithm and Web Server for Low-homology Protein Threading
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Toyota Technological Institute at Chicago is awarded a grant to develop a long-term sustainable web server for low-homology protein threading by making use of the NSF-sponsored cyberinfrastructure Open Science Grid (OSG). The OSG has been proved to be very useful in many research areas including protein folding, protein docking, geoscience and particle physics . The specific goals of this research are: (1) To develop a public protein threading web server that can thread a single protein sequence to the whole template database within minutes and thus, provide service to a large number of users. The server will use OSG, which can easily distribute millions of jobs to the supercomputers around USA, as the back-end computing engine so that our server can run jobs on thousands of CPUs free of charge and we can also easily maintain the server in the very long term beyond the funding period of this project at almost no cost. (2) To customize the web server specifically for low-homology protein threading by incorporating a profile-entropy dependent scoring function into the server. The server will significantly improve modeling capability of low-homology proteins, for which existing protein modeling programs cannot generate good models. The server developed by this project will help both individual biologists and experienced bioinformatics teams analyze the structure and function of proteins without solved structures, especially those low-homology proteins from metagenomic data. This protein modeling web service will ultimately benefit the public by providing a necessary infrastructure for applied areas of study such as alternative energy sources and new medicines.

By developing a long-term sustainable web server empowered by the OSG, this project will promote the application of the NSF-sponsored cyberinfrastructure to scientific research. The development, implementation, and evaluation of the whole project will also promote the timely and effective knowledge dissemination related to structure bioinformatics and distributed/grid computing and will train students in both basic biological sciences and advanced computing techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our work has significantly advanced the state-of-the-art protein threading, especially for proteins with sparse sequence profiles and without close homologs in PDB. As shown in the well-known CASP9 and CASP10 (the 9th and 10th Critical Assessment of Structure Prediction) competition, our method generated the best results for the hardest template-based modeling targets and was voted among the most interesting and innovative ones. The technical details and result analysis are published at some premier conferences and journals such as ISMB.

Our server now is publicly available at http://raptorx.uchicago.edu and described in our paper entitled “template-based protein structure modeling using the RaptorX web server” (Nature Protocols 7, 1511–1522, 2012). Users can submit query sequences and RaptorX produces 3-class and 8-class secondary structure prediction, solvent accessibility prediction, disorder prediction, and finally the predicted 3D models. RaptorX is the first community-wide resource that is specifically designed to deal with low-homology proteins. Since its official release in August 2011, RaptorX has processed about 30000 protein sequences submitted by ~5300 users from around the world. See the server web site for more detailed demographics. RaptorX Server has also been used by some instructors as teaching materials in their classes. Our standalone threading program has been downloaded by hundreds of users around the world and integrated to some structure prediction pipelines such as David Baker’s Robetta to further advance the field of protein modeling.

The involved graduate students and postdocs, who are future academic and industry workforce, have received training in mathematical modeling, computing techniques, biological sciences and communication skills. The summer interns who helped developing the web server receive training in both web server development and biological sciences. The PI has also hosted an international visitor Prof. Zheng from the Institute of Theoretical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, a leading expert in the Chinese protein folding community. The PI has also hosted a female visitor Prof. Yingbin Liang from the ECE department of Syracuse University, who is working on information theory but would like to branch out to bioinformatics.

The PI has also given invited talks at a number of international conferences, workshops and universities such as ISMB, CASP, 2013 NSF EPSCoR Bioinformatics Workshop to Foster Collaborative Research and the 2011 Sino-foreign-interchange Workshop on Intelligence Science and Intelligent Data Engineering. The audience includes both faculty and students with diverse background (computer science, statistics, biology). Some of the audience is also from industry.
